Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: A dispatch call sends the ambulance driver through heavy city traffic to a location where a patient has a non-life-threatening injury.
Story: I glanced at my phone, the group chat buzzing with reminders about tonight’s family dinner. My stepbrother had sent a message: “Don’t be late this time, okay?” I knew how much these gatherings meant to my new family, especially since I’d missed the last one. I promised myself I’d be there, even left work early to make sure. But as I was about to clock out, the radio crackled—dispatch needed an ambulance driver for a call across town. The patient wasn’t in critical danger, but protocol demanded I respond immediately and drive safely, no matter the traffic. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my head: “Safety first, always. No shortcuts.” I could already picture my family waiting, my stepmother’s disappointed smile, my stepbrother’s teasing. The city lights blurred as I gripped the wheel, torn between the duty to my patients and the fragile trust I was building at home. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I felt the familiar ache of being pulled in two directions, knowing I couldn’t be fully present for both.
